header.abstract: The William Hugh Jansen papers (dated 1938-1979; 26 cubic feet; 89 boxes) include correspondence, notes, folklore related materials, and student projects amassed during his career as a professor at the University of Kentucky.

descriptive_summary.author: Andrew W. McGraw
descriptive_summary.title: William Hugh Jansen papers
descriptive_summary.arrangement: The collection is arranged into five series and thirteen subseries by subject.
descriptive_summary.prefercite: 2000ua146: [identification of item], William Hugh Jansen papers, 1938-1979, University of Kentucky Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: William Hugh Jansen received the third Doctorate in Folklore in the United States from the Indiana University. He was a member of the faculty of the University of Kentucky English Department from 1949-1979. Jansen became internationally known for his work on cultural stereotyping. He published fifty articles, and served as an editor of four state and regional folklore journals. He was a Fellow of the American Folklore society, a Fulbright Lecturer, a Ford Foundation Fellow, a Fellow of the National Endowment for the Humanities, a member of the International Society of Folk Narrative Research, and a delegate to the International Council of Learned Societies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Hugh Jansen papers (dated 1938-1979; 26 cubic feet; 89 boxes) include correspondence, notes, folklore related materials, and student projects amassed during his career as a professor at the University of Kentucky. The collection also contains personal research materials dating prior to Dr. Jansen's arrival at the University of Kentucky in 1949. The greater part of the collection is made up of materials acquired by Jansen in the years he taught as a member of the English Department at UK.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The intellectual rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections and Digital Programs with the exception of student papers. According to section 106 of the Copyright Law a student owns any and all rights in and to the works they create as part of their educational experiences. This does include any work a student creates within the scope of any particular class she/he takes. Use of the student materials in this collection requires consent from the student.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The student materials series contains ungraded materials produced by students of William Hugh Jansen. The bulk of the series consist of student papers and index cards of collected folklores. The folklores primarily document the Bluegrass Region of Kentucky, as well as the western and eastern parts of the state. There are a few examples of folklores collected outside of Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series contains both professional and personal correspondence both sent and received by William Hugh Jansen throughout his career. Subjects covered include participation in professional organizations, overseas programs and projects, University of Kentucky affairs, and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Professional Materials Series documents the career of William Hugh Jansen. It contains awards and achievements, international projects and committees, course mateials, participation in professional organizations, University of Kentucky affairs, folklores collected by Jansen, publications and papers, research material, and materials related to the creation of a folk archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Audio Materials subseries contains the Everett/Edwards Folklore Cassettes, recordings from the Pine Mountain Folklore Project, recorded student folklores, and recordings of William Hugh Jansen from the radio. The Everett/Edwards folklore cassettes were meant to be a teaching tool and Jansen contributed one lecture for that series. The Pine Mountain Folklore Project was designed to intensively study the status of folklore in that eastern Kentucky community. Folklores were collected by initially going door to door in the Pine Mountain Community, and later by going to recommended homes. The result is a mixture of ballads and spoken folklores.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Course Materials subseries contains materials documenting courses which William Hugh Jansen taught at the University of Kentucky as a member of the English Department. The bulk of the materials are from folklore courses and are syllabi, exams, and reading lists. All student materials have been removed in compliance with The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act.
